prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: Some relationships have been presumed to be of a fiduciary nature. Typical examples include trustee-beneficiary, principal-agent, solicitor-client and director-corporation. The courts have made it clear that in other relationships, no “hard and fast rules apply”. However, it is still possible to examine the employment-related case law to reach some general conclusions as to the distinguishing characteristics of a fiduciary.[1]

The principal attribute of a fiduciary is that the individual in question acts on behalf of another. The fiduciary may have responsibility over assets or authority over an individual. The decision as to whether an employee owes a fiduciary duty to the employer is a question of fact and will depend on the circumstances of the employment relationship. The primary issue is the level of actual responsibility held by the employee, and in particular, the power and discretion to make decisions on behalf of the employer.

A notable case dealing with fiduciary duty is the Supreme Court of Canada's decision in LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.[2] While LAC Minerals was not an employment law case, the Supreme Court did bring the legal concepts of fiduciary duty and confidential information into the spotlight. In particular, the court considered whether a mining company, LAC Minerals Ltd., in discussing a possible joint venture with a second mining company, International Corona Resources Ltd., owed the latter a fiduciary duty.[3]

Despite the fact that the majority of the Supreme Court of Canada, per Sopinka J., were unwilling to impose a fiduciary duty, the LAC Minerals decision provides a summary of the court's view of the requirements necessary for such a finding. While the court concluded that there was no precise test, certain characteristics have been so frequently found in fiduciary relationships that they serve as a guide. Sopinka J. quoted with approval the characteristics set forth by Wilson J. in Frame v. Smith,[4] as follows:
The fiduciary has scope for the exercise of some discretion or power.
The fiduciary can unilaterally exercise that power or discretion so as to affect the beneficiary's legal or practical interests.
The beneficiary is peculiarly vulnerable to or at the mercy of the fiduciary holding the discretion or power.[5]

While the Supreme Court acknowledged that a fiduciary relationship can exist even though all three characteristics are not present, Sopinka J. stated that the third characteristic, vulnerability, is indispensable.[6] However, the policy objectives underlying fiduciary relationships will not generally apply to business entities dealing at arm's length.[7] Fiduciary obligations can arise even where there is no confidentiality agreement.[8]

An alleged ad hoc fiduciary was not found in a situation of a creditor-debtor situation, in circumstances where the Supreme Court of Canada took the opportunity to go back to some basic principles of fiduciary law. The main question considered by the Supreme Court of Canada in Perez v. Galambos[9] was whether the Court of Appeal was correct to find the appellants owed and breached fiduciary duties to the respondent Perez who had made sizeable advances of cash to her employer, the appellant law firm founded by Galambos. Perez made these advances voluntarily, much on her initiative and often without informing Galambos beforehand. When the firm was placed in receivership and Galambos went bankrupt, she found herself an unsecured creditor. She recovered nothing. Perez's claims failed at trial where the judge found that her rights were those of a creditor and nothing more.[10]

The Court of Appeal set aside that decision concluding that Perez was entitled to equity's protection because there were fiduciary duties owed to her by the appellants which they had breached. Writing for the Court of Appeal, Rowles J.A. concluded that Galambos had breached an ad hoc fiduciary duty.[11]

The Court of Appeal found that the parties' relationship was similar in nature to the “power-dependency” relationship found in Norberg v. Wynrib.[12] The Court of Appeal's conclusion that Galambos had gained a position of overriding power or influence over Perez was directly at odds with the clear findings of fact at trial. Cromwell, J. observed that the Court of Appeal had in effect retried the case and substituted its view of the facts and their significance for that of the trial judge. This was not the court's function on appeal and it erred in law by doing so.[13]

The Court of Appeal held that, in the case of a “power-dependency” relationship, a fiduciary duty may arise even in the absence of a mutual understanding that one party would act only in the interests of the other. The Supreme Court of Canada disagreed. While a mutual understanding may not always be necessary, it is fundamental to ad hoc fiduciary duties that there be an undertaking by the fiduciary, which may be either express or implied, that the fiduciary will act in the best interests of the other party. In other words, while it may not be necessary for the beneficiary in all cases to consent to this undertaking, it is clearly settled that the undertaking itself is fundamental to the existence of an ad hoc fiduciary relationship.[14]

An important focus of fiduciary law is the protection of one party against abuse of power by another in certain types of relationships or in particular circumstances. However, to assert that the protection of the vulnerable is the role of fiduciary law puts the matter too broadly. The law seeks to protect the vulnerable in many contexts and through many different doctrines. Fiduciary law is more concerned with the position of the parties that results from the relationship which gives rise to the fiduciary duty than with the respective positions of the parties before they enter into the relationship. Thus, while vulnerability in the broad sense resulting from factors external to the relationship is a relevant consideration, a more important one is the extent to which vulnerability arises from the relationship.[15]

A critical aspect of a fiduciary relationship is an undertaking of loyalty: the fiduciary undertakes to act in the interests of the other party. The particular relationships on which fiduciary law focusses are those in which one party is given a discretionary power to affect the legal or vital practical interests of the other.[16]

“Power-dependency” relationships are not a special category of fiduciary relationships and the law is clear that fiduciary duties will only be imposed on those who have expressly or impliedly undertaken them. Not all power-dependency relationships are fiduciary in nature, and identifying a power-dependency relationship does not, on its own, materially assist in deciding whether the relationship is fiduciary or not. It follows that there are not and should not be special rules for recognition of fiduciary duties in the case of “power-dependency” relationships.[17]

What is required in all cases of ad hoc fiduciary obligations is that there be an undertaking on the part of the fiduciary to exercise a discretionary power in the interests of that other party. This does not mean, however, that an express undertaking is required. Rather, the fiduciary's undertaking may be implied in the particular circumstances of the parties' relationship. Relevant to the enquiry of whether there is such an implied undertaking are considerations such as professional norms, industry or other common practices and whether the alleged fiduciary induced the other party into relying on the fiduciary's loyalty.[18]

The Court of Appeal erred in holding that, in the case of power-dependency relationships, a fiduciary duty may arise absent some undertaking on the part of the fiduciary to act in the interests of the other party. The Court of Appeal did not suggest that there was any such undertaking here and in any event, it would be inconsistent with the judge's factual findings to conclude that any such undertaking should be implied.[19]

It is fundamental to the existence of any fiduciary obligation that the fiduciary has a discretionary power to affect the other party's legal or practical interests. The nature of this discretionary power to affect the beneficiary's legal or practical interests may, depending on the circumstances, be quite broadly defined.

It may arise from power conferred by statute, agreement, perhaps from a unilateral undertaking or, in particular situations such as the professional advisory relationship by the beneficiary entrusting the fiduciary with information or seeking advice in circumstances that confer a source of power. While what is sufficient to constitute power in the hands of the fiduciary may be controversial in some cases, the requirement for the existence of such power in the fiduciary's hands is not. The presence of this sort of power will not necessarily on its own support the existence of an ad hoc fiduciary duty; its absence, however, negates the existence of such a duty.

The finding of the trial judge that Galambos had no discretionary power over Perez's interests that he was able to exercise unilaterally or otherwise was fatal to her claim that there was an ad hoc fiduciary duty on Galambos's part to act solely in her interests in relation to these cash advances.[20]

In Elder Advocates of Alberta Society v. Alberta[21] 12,500 residents of Alberta's long-term care facilities sued as a class, alleging that the government artificially elevated the required resident contributions to subsidize medical expenses that were properly the responsibility of government. In Alberta, chronic care for the elderly is provided through nursing homes and auxiliary hospitals. The government of Alberta is responsible for the costs of residents' medical care, but residents may be asked to contribute to the costs of their housing and meals through the payment of accommodation charges. The core of the plaintiffs' pleading of fiduciary duty was asserted as follows:

The Crown owed a fiduciary duty to the Class members with respect to the implementation and administration of the Accommodation Charge to ensure that the Accommodation Fee was fair, reasonable and justifiable, that the Accommodation Fee reflects the cost of accommodation and meals, that the Accommodation Fee was in their best interests, and that moneys paid pursuant to the Accommodation Charge would not be used to subsidize Health Care costs. [Emphasis added.][22]

The Chief Justice, speaking on behalf of the Supreme Court of Canada, emphasized that vulnerability alone is insufficient to support a fiduciary claim, citing Galambos v. Perez,[23] where Cromwell J. explained:

An important focus of fiduciary law is the protection of one party against abuse of power by another in certain types of relationships or in particular circumstances. However, to assert that the protection of the vulnerable is the role of fiduciary law puts the matter too broadly. The law seeks to protect the vulnerable in many contexts and through many different doctrines.
Cromwell J. concluded, at para. 68, that

while vulnerability in the broad sense resulting from factors external to the relationship is a relevant consideration, a more important one is the extent to which vulnerability arises from the relationship: Hodgkinson, at p. 406. [Emphasis added.][24]

For an ad hoc fiduciary duty to arise, the plaintiff must show in addition to the vulnerability arising from the relationship the following elements. First, the evidence must show that the alleged fiduciary gave an undertaking of responsibility to act in the best interests of a beneficiary.[25] The undertaking may be found in the relationship between the parties, in an imposition of responsibility by statute, or under an express agreement to act as trustee of the beneficiary's interests.[26] Second, the duty must be owed to a defined person or class of persons who must be vulnerable to the fiduciary in the sense that the fiduciary has a discretionary power over them.[27] Finally, to establish a fiduciary duty, the claimant must show that the alleged fiduciary's power may affect the legal or substantial practical interests of the beneficiary.[28]

In Foreman v. Chambers,[29] the trial judge approached the case mainly as one of alleged breach of confidence arising out of the existence of a “joint venture” between the plaintiff builder and the defendant buyer. The trial judge found that no joint venture had been agreed upon and that in any event, the elements of an action for breach of confidence had not been proven. Even if the action had been proven, he considered that no proprietary remedy would have been available on the facts and, since the builder would not have been able to acquire the property even if his alleged co-venturer had not acquired the lots, an award of damages based on the value of the property would not have been appropriate. Since there was no “evidence of a mutual understanding that one party had relinquished its own self-interest and agreed to act solely on behalf of the other party”, the trial judge found that the buyer had not been subject to a fiduciary duty vis-à-vis the builder.[30]

On appeal, the builder took issue with the trial judge's findings of fact, and in particular, his characterization of the information in question as lacking the requisite degree of confidentiality for the action of breach of confidence to lie. The main focus however, related to whether a fiduciary duty arose out of the buyer's position as a director of the mortgage lender to which the builder had applied for financing.[31]

Although the trial judge failed to determine certain factual issues, no clear error was shown in the findings that the court did make, or in the application of the law to those facts. Insofar as breach of fiduciary duty was concerned, the appellant's submission overlooked the fact that the disputed information was given to the successful buyer in his personal capacity rather than as a director of the mortgage lender, and that none of the elements of trust, vulnerability, or discretion were present to give rise to a fiduciary relationship between the builder and buyer.[32] However, the builder's claims in unjust enrichment and restitution were not fully addressed by the court and might have some prospect of success depending in part on factual questions that were not resolved by the trial judge. The appeal was allowed to the extent of remitting those claims to the Supreme Court to be dealt with should the plaintiff choose to pursue them.[33]

The builder inspected the lots in the late summer of 2003 and quickly became interested in developing them. The builder was especially attracted to Lot 9 as a site for a house for himself, and set about investigating the potential for building on both lots. Before he could make a real offer, however, he had to line up financing and satisfy himself on the matter of a legal easement.[34]

The defendant testified that even though he was a director and member of the investment committee of Highland Pacific, he had no involvement in considering any potential loan application either by the plaintiff. The trial judge made no express finding on the point.[35]

In any event, a meeting to discuss the possible pre-sale of one of the lots by the plaintiff to the defendant and the construction of a home for the defendant on that lot was held. The plaintiff alleged that an agreement was reached under which the defendant would buy both, the plaintiff would build a house for him on Lot E and for himself on Lot 9 and receive a percentage of the cost of construction of the defendant's house as his fee, and the plaintiff would pay the defendant out and acquire Lot 9 at some later time. Details of the construction and financing would also be worked out later.[36]

As far as the claim for a breach of confidence, Justice Newbury was satisfied that although the trial judge failed to make some factual determinations that might have been helpful, he was correct in concluding that no joint venture agreement ever came into existence and that most, if not all, of the information in question was not of the kind normally protected by the enforcement of a duty of confidence. In commenting that the information “needs to be difficult to assemble, assembled in an innovative manner or analyzed in an innovative manner”, the trial judge may have analogized the action for the protection of intellectual property with that for breach of confidentiality --- an analogy described as “controversial” in Cadbury Schweppes. But even if the trial judge did overemphasize the nature of the information in this case, the fact remained that any misuse was minimal, and that an in rem remedy would have been clearly inappropriate. There was no error in the trial judge's reasoning that the plaintiff failed to show that “but for” the defendant's use of confidential information received from or through the plaintiff, the builder would or could have acquired the lots. The builder did testify that until the “presale” idea was brought up in November, he had been pursuing financing from an alternative source in Ottawa; but whether such lender would have found the loan proposal any more attractive than Highland Pacific had was sheer speculation. Justice Newbury agreed with the trial judge that the defendant's use, through his agent, of information provided by the plaintiff and his agent could not give rise to a constructive trust or other proprietary remedy for breach of confidence, nor to damages based on the value of the property or the opportunity to acquire it.[37]

The argument that a fiduciary relationship existed was based largely on the fact that the defendant was a director of Highland Pacific, to which the plaintiff had applied for financing in the fall of 2003. The trial judge did not find, and the defendant denied, that he in his capacity as a director or as a member of the investment committee of Highland Pacific had anything to do with a potential loan. When the defendant was ultimately approached, it was in his personal capacity --- as a potential buyer of one of the lots for his personal use. The plaintiff could not have been under any misapprehension on this point. He did everything he could to make building on the lot attractive to the defendant, not in order to obtain financing from the company with which the defendant was associated, but in order to induce him to invest his own funds to buy the lots personally. One of the things the plaintiff did was to show various plans and other documents to the defendant without requesting any covenant of confidentiality or restriction on the recipient's use of the information.[38]

Justice Newbury concluded that each party must be regarded as having been acting at arm's length and for his own self-interest. None of the usual hallmarks used to identify fiduciary relationships was present --- the “inherent vulnerability” of one party; the existence of a discretion or the ability of the other party to affect that party's interest; trust; or an undertaking by one to act in the other's self-interest.[39]

Justice Newbury did not regard the relationship between the plaintiff and defendant as engaging the kinds of “high” policy considerations that underlie fiduciary obligations. The situation might have been different had the defendant received the information in his capacity as a director of Highland Pacific, but this was not the case. The plaintiff also had a personal interest in trying to arrange a “pre-sale” to the defendant, and in furtherance of that goal, disclosed the information --- most of it publicly available --- he had assembled. In doing so without the protection of an agreement, he took the risk that the information might prove interesting to the defendant for other reasons personal to him. The plaintiff was eager to interest the defendant in his proposal --- but he was not “at the mercy” of his discretion. The builder was free to show his information to any potential buyer or lender, and could well have negotiated an agreement of some kind with some other party the day after the meeting. Accordingly, the trial judge did not err in failing to find a fiduciary relationship between the parties, or in finding that the plaintiff had not proven an actionable breach of confidence.[40]
